reviewText:
WARNING: SPOILERS, although this movie is its own worst spoiler.
The makers of this film had a good thing going, if only they'd suspected it and dared be a bit ambiguous as to whether their motives were politically correct or not. But guess they were committed all along to making a different film than the good one this could've been. Kevin Bacon plays Martin Thiel, a disturbed young man who was traumatized by learning that his mother wanted to abort him. Considering that, even the staunchest pro-choice advocates might ought to cut him some slack if he's not firmly in their camp. As the movie goes on we see perhaps even more compelling reasons why he's traumatized. Quite apart form her intentions in his prenatal days, we see that his mother is one who would make Susan Smith seem warm and caring by comparison. The movie (unwittingly, I suppose) creates considerable sympathy for Martin. But never mind all that. This movie is firmly committed to by-the-books political correctness. Because Martin is an abortion opponent and his mother is a doctor who performs abortions, don't imagine any room for suspense here as to who must be the villain and who must be his last victim. When some of his mother's former patients show up murdered and mutilated, Martin becomes the chief suspect. At one point (somewhere around halfway through) he seems to virtually confess to his lawyer (played by Gary Oldman) that he's the killer, hinting that he carries out a sort of divine justice against those who got abortions. Unquestionably here's a disturbed guy. But wouldn't a smart suspenseful plot development from that point be the following? Martin is no killer, but in his traumatized state almost admires whoever is and almost wants to take credit for those deeds and/or protect the real killer. Meanwhile his ice queen mother is a most conflicted pshcyopath, not at all totally secure in her belief in the morality of abortion but keeps providing them to have access to knowledge of who gets them, so she can exact her "vengeance" on them. But that would mean the movie would have to settle for being ambivalent on the subject of abortion. Its makers lacked the imagination and/or courage (probably both) to make that intriguing thriller. Instead what they do make from the point of Martin's virtual confession is as morose and boring as it is predictable.

A pompous and predictable thriller that covers all-too-familiar territory, this one is about a lawyer who helps set his client free of murder charges only to find out he was guilty of that crime and of another killing. Those who prefer smart thrillers will be disappointed, but with its occassional moments of intriguing suspense and credible performances by Oldman and Bacon, it's hard to look away.

This is a thriiler worthy of high ranking Gary oldman plays the defense attorney who gets psycho Kevin Bacon aquitted of murder charges and then soon realizes the big mistake he made when his cilent starts taunting him  by killing again and again. Noteworthy performaces all around and backed up  by a memorable film score. If you want to see Kevin Bacon in a different  role that expands his acting capabilties see this film, as for Gary Oldman  this is one of his most acomplished works. A far cry from his usual bad guy  over the edge type characters. I love this film!

Noteworthy performaces all around and backed up  by a memorable film score. Its a great movie. I recommend

Oddly enough, the only believable characters in this mess-turd-piece are the supporting actors.  Gary and Kevin are both out of place and both seem lost and have fallen back on "acting", which is never a good thing.  That said, you really don't have anyone to root for or against here, which is what you need to make this sort of movie work.  It's horribly dated with the fashion and hair styles, and the legal and court and forensic jargon and usage wouldn't stand up in a movie of the week. Keep your money, I want my time back.

A very good film. Oldman, and Bacon both turn in outstanding performances. It is dated, but the story holds up. Interesting to think how far we've come with DNA, and forensic evidence - this story couldn't be made today. Well it could be made, but there is no way Bacon's psychotic killer character would have walked away from a murder wrap by discrediting an eye- witness. Regardless of how the killer burned or washed the bodies - they would find the DNA evidence necessary to put this guy away the first time.

It is a great suspenseful film with the cat and mouse between the two leads, Oldman and Bacon, very well scripted, and acted. Definitely not a waste of time. I have to wonder if all the CSI shows are the reason for some of the low ratings. This film was made in 89 - there weren't even cell phones - forget any of that CSI voodoo. Watch and enjoy an old time suspense thriller.
I've never seen the young Gary Oldman. He is a fantastic actor! The movie was hard to watch, very intense so I watched over two nights.
Put it on for back round noise while I was cleaning my room. Bad plot, bad acting, bad pro-abortion message. Well, at least my room is clean.
well played, i loved it
Wasting time to watch it!
test
Don't waste your time on this one. Old tired storyline with a dash of PC bull thrown in.

Joe Don Baker is in this movie, which should be 'nuff said!

...but for those of you not old enough to know about the J.D.B. curse let me say this:

Gary Oldman is a demi-god of the the modern screen. Kevin Bacon is seven degrees from a demi-god in any given movie. Even these two couldn't breath life into this horrific excuse of a script. Turn back now while you still can.

Old film, 1995, thatvtakes place in Boston but caught my interest. However, it turned out to be a real dud.

Attorney Ben Chase, played by Gary Oldman, as a young stud who successfully defends Martin Thiel, played by Kevin Bacon. Martin is a wealthy, playboy, and getting him acquitted of a series of brutal murders was his first real success. However, Chase later finds out  that Thiel is indeed a serial killer. Since Thiel cannot be tried again for his crimes, Chase tries to get him to incriminate himself before he can kill again.  Easier said than done.

The rest of the cast is good, but not good enough to save this film.

Not Recommended For Me.  prisrob 08-16-17

The movie sucked..but it sure made Kevin Bacon looked and acted crazy!

OMG you haven't seen this movie? But you say you LOVE Kevin Bacon? Girl chile, please! Listen, the first thing I noticed in this movie was Gary Oldman's 1980s curled coif that just screams AMBITION. Kevin Bacon is in this thing, too, and he Doesn't disappoint. His eyes are as cold as a slitherin snake's, and he just embodies INTENSENESS. I loved all the scenes of Gary Oldman's car pulling into different parking spaces then backing out, his car driving over a bridge, his car backing up, and then parking. This movie even had overhead shots of his car parking. You won't see that in a Burt Reynold's movie! Also, the scene where he just runs through a rainy park for a good 5 minutes yelling for Kevin Bacon's ass, and (spoiler) he trips over a dead woman's body and then her body rolls down the hill and lands on him. Guys, you're really missing out if you don't check out this movie. Just tell me how it ends. Also, Matthew McConaughey (Fool's Gold) could have played Both of these roles back to back. Learn better Hollywood.
Movie has aged a bit, but worth watching

I bit because it's Kevin Bacon. But this movie was just plain silly. Acting was way over the top and unbelievable. Plot was seriously unrealistic, no matter how much you suspend your disbelief. In the end, things turn out as you knew from the beginning the would. Then you'll want your two hours back, but it'll be too late.

Very dated serial killer movie. Only watched it because Gary Oldman is in it. This movie is ultra 80s, but not in a good Michael Mann kind of way. Like, everybody's hair is ridiculous but it's not balanced out by any kind of super cool directorial aesthetic. Gary Oldman's performance is not great, which is bizarre for him as he is one of the most talented actors ever to live. Kevin Bacon is pretty good, but the material doesn't give him much to work with.

Featuring an absolutely fantastic central performance by a young , odd bird , alabaster Gary Oldman , sumptuously photography , excellent supporting performances and ever increasing intensity . However ridiculous aspects are though , I've seen this picture 3 or 4 times over several decades and arrived here wanting to purchase a copy . Fun , thrilling and exciting....if you want it to be ?

Gary Oldman's Hair features at the bleeding edge of early 90's salon technology against the inestimable Kevin Bacon doing his preppy thing to the hilt. My favorite scene is when Oldman's character attempts to cool down a frantic woman and the scene takes just a few seconds too long because it honestly looks like she's about to win the physical altercation. You can almost hear the director stage whispering off screen, "She's winning Gary!"

Good movie

I found this movie too predictable.  A better twist at the end would have been for his Mom/Dad or brother/sister to have committed the murders.

The law - so many ethical violations from the very beginning that the character would be sure to get a new trial and evidence thrown out.  A smart attorney wanting to avoid appeals would have withdrawn and just been a witness from the very beginning, if he knew he could not zealously represent his client.  They should have consulted an attorney when they wrote the script.

Gary Oldman and Kevin Bacon are a great combo to headline any movie. I had seen this gem when it first came out many years ago and was captivated by it's atmosphere and gritty subject matter. It has been a favorite of mine since that time, and I enjoyed watching it once again.
Not too bad....I like Kevin Bacon, even as a bad guy.

KEVIN BACON is without a doubt one of my very favorite actors and never turns in a bad performance.  He's excellent in this
film as always but the movie itself is somewhat forgettable.  The plot is uneven and to a certain degree quite predictable.  There could have been plot twists to make the movie much more interesting and compelling.  I'm not exactly sure what the missing component is in this film but it's somehow not quite the suspenseful thriller that it might have been.
rather convoluted, not easy to follow and not very interesting

I really anticipated watching this movie because I love the work both these men do. In that regard I wasn't disappointed.  But even with the suburb talent these to brought to the screen they couldn't do it alone.  The premise was good but script was awful.  The director's attempt at high drama just missed the mark.  The scene where Mr. Old man finds the body should have had the audience coming out of their chairs instead I was contemplating turning the movie off.  It dragged and was too predictable.  I really should have turned it off at that point because the rest of the story was disappointing and not worth your time.

This video was attention-getting.  I was surprised at the ending, though.  Would have loved to see him go to trial.  Perhaps more information could have been revealed about any other women he killed because they had abortions.

Could not even finish watching -- it's that bad. Big star cast -- probably at the beginning of their careers. Kindest word for this movie is: BORING. Watch it if you suffer from insomnia -- definitely put you to sleep.

I saw this movie on the plane and unlike most movies I pick for my several hour flight, I found myself looking out the window much of the time.  Awful movie, kept thinking it would get better.  I should have shut it off and played Angry Birds.

I forgotten I had seen this one before long ago. The film is ok, it has been done many times over after it with same idea. The acting on both was good enough. Kinda of weird to see the commissioner Gary Oldman (from the Batman series) so young but still doing at good job at acting. Kevin Bacon, baby face here had to imagine him as a serial killer but yet still this must have been where he learned how to come up with that sinister face he uses, when he plays the bad guy. He's a good actor and I would say he plays a 'good BAD guy" part in this one as others he's done. If you never seen it, it would be a good hour and half to see it of your time, you won't regret, but if you're 50 years old, it will probable make you feel even older when you see these two at it.
One of my favorite Gary Oldman movies with great cast including devilish Kevin Bacon & Tess Harper saving the day!

Paul Bernardo wasn't a nice guy.  Now we know that he didn't have very good taste, either.

Mr. Bernardo liked this film so much, he even changed his last name to "Teale," a slight variation on the name of the Kevin Bacon character in "Criminal Law."  I just read the book "Invisible Darkness" by Stephen Williams -- a slightly biased but excellent read by a very good crime writer -- and in that book, Mr. Williams described how this film was Mr. Bernardo's -- or is that Mr. Teale's? -- favorite film.  If you know anything about Mr. Bernardo, you might say, "Not surprising."

Now, the cast in this film is top notch.  I am a Kevin Bacon fan -- I believe that he has done some excellent work throughout his career -- and Gary Oldman gave a performance of a lifetime in "Dracula," even though Keanu Reeves did his best to pull him down.  (I'm teasing a bit.  Mr. Reeves wasn't half bad in that film.)  But the female lead and female supporting actors here?  I thought they were fine with what they had to work with, but I can't remember seeing them ever in anything else.

The problem with "Criminal Law":  well OK; there are not just a few.  But for me, there was way too much exposition, particularly by the Kevin Bacon character just before he was going to do something nasty.  In my opinion, if you were a serial killer, you probably wouldn't have too much time for chit chat in most scenarios, since, well, your "prey" would be fighting back.  That prey wouldn't just be standing there listening to you ramble, as if you were accepting an Academy Award nomination, a nomination that surely no one in this borderline film ever received.

To Mr. Bacon and Mr. Oldman I say:  "Don't take it too hard.  After all, I'm not a professional film critic.  Not only that, you both have done fine work in your careers, so just let this one go."  To Mr. Bernardo I say:  "Keep your day job, which would probably be banging your head against the wall in a 6 foot by 10 foot cell in solitary.  With your picks in film, you'll surely never be a film critic."

While this isn't a new release, by any means, the theme of this movie is timeless and thrilling.  A psycho-thriller that leaves you on the edge of your seat until the end.  Stellar performances by vey young Gary Oldham and Kevin Bacon with a great supporting cast by notable actors.  A must see.

The backstory surrounding "Criminal Law" is more interesting than the film itself. Infamous Canadian Schoolgirl Killer Paul Bernardo was obsessed with this film  and with Kevin Bacon's twisted character Martin Thiel. Mr Bernardo even changed his last named to "Teale" shortly before his 1993 arrest, in a bizarre nod to this mediocre film. Gary Oldman plays hot-shot Ben Chase, an Attorney who manages to get Thiel aquitted of murder charges more than once. Thiel, a preppy son-of-an-Abortionist, loves his clothes, boats, and doing creative things with flaming diapers. Tess Harper, Joe Don Baker, and Sean McCann play the cops in earnest, but this is Oldman and Bacon's show. Neither is especially successful here: Oldman, with a bad 80's haircut, is wild-eyed and soaking wet for most of the film and Bacon lacks the depth to play his role. Christian Bale did a much better job playing a near-identical role in "American Psycho," a better film than this.
I'm a fan of Kevin Bacon performances.  This storyline had some interesting twists and plot developments in it!  Not a happily-ever-after drama, but it did present some things to think about!

Despite the big 80's hair this movie still holds up as a good thriller.  Kevin Bacon is young, startlingly good looking and super ingratiating as a privileged yuppie in this "did he? didn't he?" tale of a serial killer.  Gary Oldman is doing one of his first stints as an American and his accent is pretty good.  For those who are fans of both actors, it's a movie worth revisiting!
I owned this movie as a vhs tape and wanted to have it on dvd. the price was right and I am happy with my purchase!
Gary Oldman can play ANY part ! He is truly a great actor. He also like's challenging part's. You should see it.

Both Gary Oldman and Kevin Bacon are superb in this thriller set in Boston.  In both the courtroom and in the darkness of the depravity of the mind, this tense drama plays out to a powerful conclusion.

Oldman plays Ben Chase, a young attorney bouyed by his early successes who defends Martin Thiel, accused of murder.  Chase realizes that Thiel not only is guilty, but has not given up his murderous ways; in fact, he is a serial killer.

The plot is pretty simple; Chase realizes that he has unleased a killer whose mind has been unhinged by his mother's decision to abort him as a developing baby.  What does an ethical man do when he knows someone has used him in a horrific way?

Tess Harper does her fine usual job (and looks good doing it) as detective Stillwell, and Joe Don Baker (detective Mesel) is good playing the character he usually plays, a gruff but effective supporting character.

The true interest in the film is the main character's acting.  The staging is well done, the cinematography is fine.  The final scene illustrates the fact that there is often little separating the law from the crime.  Perhaps we are all capable of acting on our more base impulses. There are a few plot holes (such as, where are the bailiffs and the police in the climatic courthouse scene).  But over-all, it's a fine movie.

Recommended.  Three and one-half stars.

Criminal Law is a classic. This is a great film to watch. Gary Oldman is great! Kevin Bacon is awesome! This film deals with some serious subject matter, but if you can get thru that then you won't be disappointed. I've read some other reviews on this film (not all good). But films are for our entertainment, and I was entertained!

I had this on VHS for years so you can imagine I'm thrilled to have it available on DVD now. I know a number of people that enjoy this movie. Any critic that thinks this movie lacks wit is criminally insane. This is a fine thriller with Gary Oldman and Kevin Bacon turning in excellent performances. When a Boston attorney, played by Oldman realizes he has got his client off a murder charge when he was guilty, he tries to figure out away to make retribution. But the killer, played by Bacon, isn't going to make that easy at all. If you enjoy this be sure to catch "The Juror" and "The Client".

Oldman is the real focus of this movie for me, this must be an early film of his and he's as good in this role as he is as a more mature actor. I find him able to handle any role or character type that comes his way.
Kevin Bacon is OK as the twisted son of a mother who does threapeutic abortions (pro- lifers this is not an arguement pro or con just a description of the character his mother portrays).

The premise is set up pretty good and the finale' is an ironic twist that helps give the movie some further attachment to its title.

I rate it 4 because there have been better performances in other films by both lead characters.

Interesting analysis of morality.  Kevin Bacon plays a man whose sense of right is so out of touch with society that he may be a criminal.  If you look past some of the classic Joe Don Baker dialogue ("Son, in all my years of police work, I've learned one thing:  a crazy killer is crazy.  And he will kill you.") you might just see an interesting portrait of a people who are willing to pay the consequences of their actions in order to do what they consider the right thing.

IF I remember correctly, this film was the topic of about 4 of my papers in college.

This movie review is based on the Laser Disc, not the DVD.  Seeing how this is not available on DVD, and not even being sold by outside sellers tells me that they may never have released it on this format.  That, based on my memory of the quality of the Laser Disc release, does not surprise me in the least.

I had this movie on Laser Disc purchased for me by an ex-girlfriend, and definitely shows to me her lack of fortitude in choosing movies based on their quality.  But, who am I to look a gift horse in the mouth.

I thought this was the most asinine movie.  It was schlock full of loose strings, un-explaineable (though the tried) plot twists, and complete lack of plot logic. I thought a defense lawyer was supposed to defend you?  Right?  And I thought that all lawyers sign an ethics agreement to support and treat the client with all due respect.  Maybe I'm not using the right terms, but what the hell!

Gary Oldman is a defense lawyer, and defends and gets a defendant off (Kevin Bacon) and supposedly, figures out Kevin is actually guilty of the former and a new crime, and suddenly becomes the defender of justice.  Maybe somebody better tell the screenplay writer, that defense lawyers defend the "guilty" and do not work for the State Prosecuter's Office, or even the Public Defender's office.  If he accepts the case, and then acts as the Detective, he is immediately guilty of injustice to his client, and the viewer will immediately turn off.

However, for some reasons, I didn't turn it off.  I was immediately fascinated by the absurdity of this plot.  And the overacting.  And the stupidity!  Gary Oldman and the Lady Detective deserve the Overacting Raspberry award of the year!  Their on screen interactions were ludicrous and hilarious at the same time!

Another reviewer mentioned that Gary Oldman has an American accent.  I actually didn't know he was British when I first saw this movie, and fascinated with how well he could imitate a British accent in his other movies.  Of course, I have since learned his country of origin, and am equally impressed with his American and British accents in many of his films.  He truly is a glorious actor.

Even in this movie, he steals most of his scenes, and deserves credit for his wonderful acting.  But the movie is awful, and not even he can save it!

If you want to laugh, try to find this on VHS, or even Laser Disc (I still have my copy) but DVD format seems to be up in the air at this time.  But under no circumstances pay more than $1.25 for this tripe!

MC White said:  Not even worth a rental.  See if you can find it for free online.
A very skillful attempt at masking bad writing in a cloak of mystery.

Oldman is so very, very off in this one. The overacting is painful to watch, yet the words coming out of his mouth are so bland, so uninspiring. The script plods through what could have been an interesting storyline. I got about 1/3 the way into it until my jaw hurt so bad from gritting my teeth as I was enduring it that I had to stop. The production is just a notch or two up from a high school play - lighting, costumes, hair, makeup, editing & so on. I can watch just about anything, but this, this was beyond my capabilities.

Very suspenseful old school crime story line with the extra twist being the psychological  "bridge" built by killer between himself and his attorney. I've aways loved Kevin Bacon and his and Gary Oldman's performances didn't disappoint.  Interesting house and park images gave this an "film noir" feel, as well.
This is one of the worst, overacted movies I have ever seen.
I like most Gary Oldman movies. Good one.
Gary Old man is brilliant as usual.
Thank You!
one of my favorite movies.

I never watch a movie without doing something else on the side; I play a simple game, look at my email, write lists, talk to my children or husband, give directions, etc., etc...but, though I tried, I could not be distracted from this movie.  I thought it was great!
Somewhere that they list the symptoms of insanity, or at the very least stupidity, has to be listed "going after a serial killer on my own that the police cannot catch".
